data.name: Title00
data.value: Web Site Administration Tool Security Tab

data.name: WebSiteAdministrationToolSecurityTab01
data.value: Web Site Administration Tool Security Tab

data.name: WebSiteAdministrationToolSecurityTab02
data.value: Use the Security tab of the Web Site Administration Tool to manage rules for securing specific resources in the Web application. ASP.NET uses a security system that lets you restrict access to specific user accounts or the roles to which the user accounts belong. With the Security tab, you manage user accounts, roles, and access rules for the Web site. Before using the Security tab for the first time, use the Security Setup Wizard to configure basic security settings for the Web site.

data.name: Introduction01
data.value: Introduction

data.name: Introduction02
data.value: ASP.NET security is based on the concepts of user accounts, roles, and access rules and lets you restrict access to your Web application resources to only the user accounts that you specify. Security settings are established using a combination of configuration settings and data stored in a database (or other data store). User accounts and roles that you create are stored in the database and access rules are stored in the Web.config file.

data.name: Introduction03
data.value: You can configure your application to use the following types of security, which depend on how the Web site will be used:

data.name: Introduction04
data.value: Forms-based authentication (From the Internet)

data.name: Introduction05
data.value: Forms-based authentication is used for Web sites that are made available to the Internet. Forms-based authentication uses the ASP.NET membership system to manage individual user accounts and groups (roles). User account information is stored in a local database or in a Microsoft SQL Server database. You can use the ASP.NET logon controls to create a logon page where users can enter their credentials.

data.name: Introduction06
data.value: Integrated Microsoft Windows authentication (From a local network)

data.name: Introduction07
data.value: Windows authentication interacts with Windows security, using the logon credentials that users provide when they log on to Windows. Therefore, Windows authentication is suited for intranet scenarios, where users have logged on to a Windows-based network. You do not have to create a logon page, because users are automatically logged on to your application with their Windows credentials.

data.name: Introduction08
data.value: Use the Users section of the Security tab to complete the following tasks:

data.name: Introduction09
data.value: Create, edit, and delete registered user accounts for the Web site.

data.name: Introduction10
data.value: View a list of all registered user accounts for the Web site.

data.name: Introduction11
data.value: Change the authentication method that is used by the Web site.

data.name: Introduction12
data.value: Note You can create and manage user accounts, if you chose the From the Internet option for your authentication type (if you are using forms-based authentication). If you chose the From a local network option as your authentication type (if you using integrated Windows authentication), you cannot manage individual user accounts. If you change the authentication type, any user information that you have created will be lost. Additionally, access rules might no longer work in the way that you configured them. Generally, you should select an authentication type only when you first configure the Web site.

data.name: Introduction13
data.value: Use the Roles section of the Security tab to group user accounts, which makes it easier to assign permissions (authorization).

data.name: Introduction14
data.value: Use the Access Rules section of the Security tab to allow or deny access for specified pages to specific user accounts or to all user accounts that belong in a specified role. Typically, you use an access rule to restrict pages for some user accounts.

data.name: CreatingUsers01
data.value: Creating Users

data.name: CreatingUsers02
data.value: You can create and manage user accounts, if you have set the authentication type to From the Internet (forms authentication). To change authentication types, click Select authentication type.

data.name: CreatingUsers03
data.value: To create user accounts

data.name: CreatingUsers04
data.value: Click Create user, and then specify the following information.

data.name: CreatingUsers05
data.value: User Name

data.name: CreatingUsers06
data.value: Enter the name for the user account to create.

data.name: CreatingUsers07
data.value: Password

data.name: CreatingUsers08
data.value: Enter the password for User Name. Passwords are case sensitive.

data.name: CreatingUsers09
data.value: Confirm Password

data.name: CreatingUsers10
data.value: Re-enter Password.

data.name: CreatingUsers11
data.value: E-mail

data.name: CreatingUsers12
data.value: Enter the e-mail address for User Name.

data.name: CreatingUsers13
data.value: The Web Site Administration Tool does not confirm whether the address that you enter is a valid e-mail address, but it does validate that the e-mail address conforms to the correct format for e-mail addresses.

data.name: CreatingUsers14
data.value: Security Question

data.name: CreatingUsers15
data.value: Enter a question to ask the user when they need to reset or recover their password.

data.name: CreatingUsers16
data.value: Security Answer

data.name: CreatingUsers17
data.value: Enter the answer to Security Question.

data.name: CreatingUsers18
data.value: Active User

data.name: CreatingUsers19
data.value: Select this option to enable this user account as an active (current) user of the site. If you do not select this option, the user information is stored in the database, but the user cannot log on to the Web site.

data.name: CreatingUsers20
data.value: Roles

data.name: CreatingUsers21
data.value: Select the roles for User Name. You create roles separately. For more information, see the next section.

data.name: CreatingRoles01
data.value: Creating Roles

data.name: CreatingRoles02
data.value: To create roles

data.name: CreatingRoles03
data.value: On the Security tab, click Enable roles.

data.name: CreatingRoles04
data.value: Click Create or Manage roles.

data.name: CreatingRoles05
data.value: In the New role name box, enter a name for the role to create, such as Administrator, Member, or Guest, and then click Add Role.

data.name: CreatingRoles06
data.value: To add user accounts to roles

data.name: CreatingRoles07
data.value: On the Security tab, click Manage Users, and then click Edit User.

data.name: CreatingRoles08
data.value: Under Roles, select the roles for the user account.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules01
data.value: Creating Access Rules

data.name: CreatingAccessRules02
data.value: To create access rules

data.name: CreatingAccessRules03
data.value: On the Security tab, click Create access rules.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules04
data.value: Specify the following options:

data.name: CreatingAccessRules05
data.value: Select a directory for this rule

data.name: CreatingAccessRules06
data.value: You can choose to create a rule that applies to the whole site or to only a specific subdirectory. In the directory structure display for the Web site, select the directory to which the rule applies.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules07
data.value: Under Rule applies to, specify how to apply the rule.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules08
data.value: Role

data.name: CreatingAccessRules09
data.value: Select Role, and then in the list, select the name of the role to which the access rule applies.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules10
data.value: User

data.name: CreatingAccessRules11
data.value: Select User, and then enter the name of the user account to which the access rule applies. If you are using ASP.NET membership (Web site security is set to From the internet), you can also use the Search for users feature.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules12
data.value: All users

data.name: CreatingAccessRules13
data.value: Select this option to apply the rule to all visitors to the Web site.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules14
data.value: Note Be careful when you create a rule with the All users option. Because rules are applied in order, you can unintentionally create a rule that prevents all users from accessing a folder.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules15
data.value: Anonymous users

data.name: CreatingAccessRules16
data.value: Select this option to apply this rule to anonymous (non-registered) user accounts only.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules17
data.value: Typically, you choose the Anonymous users option to restrict (deny) access for users who are not logged on.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules18
data.value: Permission

data.name: CreatingAccessRules19
data.value: Select Allow to give access to the specified directory for the specified user account or role.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules20
data.value: Select Deny to not allow access to the specified directory for the specified user account or role.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules21
data.value: For example, to prevent users who are not logged on (anonymous) from viewing pages in a folder, click the folder, select Anonymous users, and then select Deny.

data.name: CreatingAccessRules22
data.value: Sometimes, you might have to create multiple rules for the same folder in order to establish the correct permissions. For example, you might create a rule that denies access to anonymous user accounts and a second rule that denies access to user accounts in the role of Guest. That way, only users who are logged on and in another group can access the folder.

data.name: BehindtheScenes01
data.value: Behind the Scenes

data.name: BehindtheScenes02
data.value: The Web Site Administration Tool manages security information in the following two places:

data.name: BehindtheScenes03
data.value: The Web.config file at the root of the Web site.

data.name: BehindtheScenes04
data.value: The site provider database that is used to store user and group information.

data.name: Web.configSettings01
data.value: Web.config Settings

data.name: Web.configSettings02
data.value: The Web.config settings that are managed through the Security tab are the <authorization>, <roleManager>, and <authentication> sections.

data.name: Web.configSettings03
data.value: The following code example is the Web.config file that is created by the Web Site Administration Tool within a restricted subdirectory of the Web site. Access to the restricted subdirectory is allowed for administrators and denied for anonymous users.

data.name: Database01
data.value: Database

data.name: Database02
data.value: When you use the default data provider, the Web Site Administration Tool creates entries in the default ASP.NET database. By default, the Web Site Administration Tool creates a database in the App_Data folder of the Web site. However, using the Provider tab, you can specify that application information for user accounts and roles be kept in another database (for example, retrieving role information from the Windows user database). For detailed information, see Web Site Administration Tool Provider Tab.

data.name: MoreInformation01
data.value: More Information

data.name: MoreInformation02
data.value: For more information about the settings that are managed in the Security tab, in the .NET Framework documentation, see the following topics:

data.name: MoreInformation03
data.value: Managing Users with ASP.NET Membership

data.name: MoreInformation04
data.value: Limiting Access to ASP.NET Web Sites

data.name: MoreInformation05
data.value: ASP.NET Configuration Overview

data.name: SeeAlso01
data.value: See Also

data.name: SeeAlso02
data.value: Web Site Administration Tool Overview

data.name: SeeAlso03
data.value: Web Site Administration Tool Application Tab

data.name: SeeAlso04
data.value: Web Site Administration Tool Provider Tab

data.name: SeeAlso05
data.value: Web Site Administration Tool Internals
